--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:

> Ken=
's response to Daniel Tuohy's yesterday briefly touched on
> evolution of f=
eedforward-only networks and this is somethign I've been
> meaning to think=
 about for some time. My initial thoughts on how to do
> this relatively ef=
ficiently are as follows:

Hi!

Using brain during xmas has led me to this =
conclusion.
I've identified four types of networks that potentially could b=
e nice to
evolve.

1:
First is the Feed Forward network. This kind of netwo=
rk is very fast to
compute. nice :)

2:
Add memory of old activations of si=
ze N to each node in the Feed Forward
network and allow genes to go from th=
ese old computed values. This kind of
network does not contain any loops so=
 it is as fast to compute as the Feed
Forward network. super nice :)

3:
Ne=
tworks containing short circuit loops. Looping is needed to compute these
k=
ind of networks which can make them slow. :(

4:
Add memory of old activati=
ons to network type 3 and you get this kind of
network.

Dunno what network=
s 2,3 & 4 are called but I think they all fall under the
category recurrent=
 networks, but I do feel they have different properties when computing them=
 so I've separated them into three types. Feel free to educate me about the=
ir names if anyone knows!

One can also have two bit flags so one can choos=
e if nodes with zero inputs, and nodes with zero outputs should be allowed =
to exist.

Network types 1 & 2 I support in my implementation, and later I =
probably will add support for 3 & 4 to make it complete.

/Magnus
